description:
Following the setup instructions for ec2-api and uploading an image using nova-objectstore, I'm hitting an error with register_image()

(.nova-venv)pvoccio@ubuntu:~/Code/openstack$ uec-publish-tarball ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1.tar.gz mybucket
Sun Jan 30 21:52:48 CST 2011: ====== extracting image ======
kernel : ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1-vmlinuz
ramdisk: ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1-initrd
image  : ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1.img
Sun Jan 30 21:52:49 CST 2011: ====== bundle/upload kernel ======
failed to register ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1-vmlinuz.manifest.xml
failed: euca-register mybucket/ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1-vmlinuz.manifest.xml
register_image() takes at least 2 non-keyword arguments (1 given)failed to upload kernel

http://paste.openstack.org/show/600/
title: Can't upload an image using euca2ools or uec-publish-tarball

comments.content:
Following the setup instructions for ec2-api and uploading an image using nova-objectstore, I'm hitting an error with register_image()

(.nova-venv)pvoccio@ubuntu:~/Code/openstack$ uec-publish-tarball ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1.tar.gz mybucket
Sun Jan 30 21:52:48 CST 2011: ====== extracting image ======
kernel : ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1-vmlinuz
ramdisk: ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1-initrd
image  : ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1.img
Sun Jan 30 21:52:49 CST 2011: ====== bundle/upload kernel ======
failed to register ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1-vmlinuz.manifest.xml
failed: euca-register mybucket/ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1-vmlinuz.manifest.xml
register_image() takes at least 2 non-keyword arguments (1 given)failed to upload kernel

http://paste.openstack.org/show/600/
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~pvo

comments.content:
Greetings, Paul!

Not sure if this will work, but I've ran into some images that I had to specify the architecture in the command, e.g.  uec-publish-tarball ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1.tar.gz mybucket x86_64

I don't know the specifics, but there is some images that this info is in the metadata and it's not needed, and others you have to specify.  I ran into when I was trying to boot a custom image that I made.  Give that a try, not sure if it's your problem, but worth a shot.

Cheers
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~wayne-walls

comments.content:
Greetings, gentlemen!

I am running XenServer 5.6, with Ubuntu 10.04 domU.  All nova services, and glance are running from source.  I have two images uploaded via glance, and one instance of each.  They are both showing up in my XenCenter console.  The first, a lucid image, is stuck on boot.  The second, a mave image, gives me the following output via console:

#####

Gave up waiting for root device.  Common problems:
 - Boot args (cat /proc/cmdline)
   - Check rootdelay= (did the system wait long enough?)
   - Check root= (did the system wait for the right device?)
 - Missing modules (cat /proc/modules; ls /dev)
FATAL: Could not load /lib/modules/2.6.35-22-virtual/modules.dep: No such file or directory
FATAL: Could not load /lib/modules/2.6.35-22-virtual/modules.dep: No such file or directory
ALERT! /dev/xvda1 does not exist. Dropping to a shell!


BusyBox v1.13.3 (Ubuntu 1:1.13.3-1ubuntu11) built-in shell (ash)
Enter 'help' for a list of built-in commands.

(initramfs) cat /proc/cmdline
root=/dev/xvda1

#####

I ran through the 'common problems,' and everything /looks/kosher.  Do either of you know what could be causing my VM is starting properly?  This is the same image that I use with my nova-objectstore deployments w/ ec2 API, and I have not had an issue.  I assume there must be something going on with the way XenServer is handling the drive assignments?

#####
Here is my nova.conf:
root@xbuntu01:~/openstack# cat /root/openstack/nova.conf
--verbose
--nodaemon
--sql_connection=mysql://root:nova@127.0.0.1/nova
--network_manager=nova.network.manager.FlatManager
--image_service=nova.image.glance.GlanceImageService
--flat_network_bridge=xenbr0
--connection_type=xenapi
--xenapi_connection_url=https://184.106.73.71
--xenapi_connection_username=root
--xenapi_connection_password=openstack
--allow_admin_api=true
--xenapi_remap_vbd_dev=false
#####


Any insight greatly appreciated!


Cheers,


Wayne A. Walls
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~wayne-walls

comments.content:
Is that image a Maverick image?  If so, Ubuntu decided to be smart and change the device type from xvda back to sda. Try putting sda in your fstab/root device.  Bet it boots then.

Ant

On Jan 31, 2011, at 6:19 PM, "Wayne Walls" <email address hidden> wrote:

This is the same image that I use with my nova-objectstore deployments w/ ec2 API, and I have not had an issue.  I assume there must be something going on with the way XenServer is handling the drive assignments?
>

comments.content:
It is a Maverick image, and just to clarify...if I change,
"--xenapi_remap_vbd_dev=false" to "true", I get an /sda error when I try
to boot.  Are you proposing taking the image, mounting via loopback,
editing fstab, and reuploading the image?

Cheers,

wayne

comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~wayne-walls

comments.content:
Yeah, if that's what you're getting on instance boot, then it's definitely
the fstab.  That's one of the reasons we had to add the remap flag for the
domU as well.  Why they decided to flip the device names again... who
knows?  :/

-Ant

comments.content:
I haven't really messed with ext4 in the domUs.

https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/705790

Really sounds like it's just a mismatch between sda vs xvda.  This is the
related Ubuntu bug:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/684875

[Ant]ony Messerli
The Rackspace Cloud
w: 210.312.4308
c: 210.364.1829

comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~antonym

comments.content:
Yeah, Ubuntu changed the Xen block device handling in their kernel.  They made it match what Amazon do, but that broke every other Xen installation in the world.  They reverted pretty quickly when they realised what they'd done, but it made it into Maverick by the sounds of it:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/684875
http://www.gossamer-threads.com/lists/xen/devel/192003
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~ewanmellor

comments.content:
Hmm, two different issues seem to have been reported here as bug 710452

Wayne: if you still experience issue could you file a separate bug about it ?
Paul: Did Wayne suggestion fix the issue for you ?
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~ttx

comments.content:
I ran into the exact same problems at the OP. 

Both trying to register manually and with uec-publish-tarball give the above mentioned error on register_image(). 

The x86_64 does not help:

$ uec-publish-tarball ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1.tar.gz mybucket x86_64
Wed Feb  9 10:56:24 CET 2011: ====== extracting image ======
kernel : ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1-vmlinuz
ramdisk: ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1-initrd
image  : ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1.img
Wed Feb  9 10:56:27 CET 2011: ====== bundle/upload kernel ======
failed to register ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1-vmlinuz.manifest.xml
failed: euca-register mybucket/ttylinux-uec-amd64-12.1_2.6.35-22_1-vmlinuz.manifest.xml
register_image() takes at least 2 non-keyword arguments (1 given)failed to upload kernel


The uec doesn't matter either: both the Unbuntu and ttylinux uec fail.

Ubuntu 10.10:
cloud-utils: 0.16ubuntu1
euca2ools: 1.2-0ubuntu11.1
python-boto: 1.9b-1ubuntu3

(Installed Bexar via: http://wiki.openstack.org/NovaInstall/Bexar )
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~hugoideler

comments.content:
Can't reproduce that, and it looks like a client issue (python-boto / euca2ools), not a nova issue.
In particular it looks like you're using a boto that doesn't have the patch from bug 504530.
However your Ubuntu 10.10 versions look sane...
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~ttx

comments.content:
I checked, but http://bazaar.launchpad.net/~vcs-imports/boto/trunk/revision/1001#boto/ec2/connection.py (from #504530) is applied in my system onto /usr/share/pyshared/boto/ec2/connection.py .

This was just an unmodified 10.10 Ubuntu, but I can try a reinstall from a fresh iso.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~hugoideler

comments.content: Oops, the patch was unapplied in /usr/local/lib/python2.6/dist-packages/boto/ec2/connection.py .
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~hugoideler

comments.content: With pip: the line boto==1.9b in tools/pip-requires downloads a version which does not have the patch from #504530 applied. Using the Ubuntu version from python-boto instead does work.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~hugoideler

comments.content: Closing as "not a nova bug". You should use uec-publish-tarball / euca2ools / boto from outside venv to benefit from the good Ubuntu patches.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~ttx
